Value: The following guidelines have been written, taking into account the local population and resources, most readily available to our organization. Whenever possible, the guidelines should be followed as written. However, patients should always be treated individually. At times it may be appropriate to stray from these guidelines: for individual patients or if specific resources are low. Please always ensure the patient is aware of the name and dosage of every medication prescribed. This will allow them to inform our doctors on future visits and/or continue to purchase as needed. This can easily be done using our Floating Doctors prescription pads (placing a script in with each bag of medications), please keep in mind all patients are not able to read written Spanish. If a patient is diagnosed with a chronic condition, requiring long-term medication, please fill in a Floating Doctors card for the patient. Details of the diagnosis, medication, blood pressure and blood sugar should be documented and the card given to the patient. The cards can be modified on future visits, depending on the treatment. The cards will allow the patient, and any doctor seeing the patient, to know what we are treating them for. In clinic the British National Formulary (BNF) for adults and children will be available. Please use to BNF to check any medications you are not familiar with using, particularly side effects and contraindications (for example in breast feeding and pregnancy) as they are not all listed in these guidelines. The following guidelines cover the treatment of the most common presentations that will be seen in our clinics. As you will discover, practicing medicine in a remote setting requires a different approach. The following guidelines were written with evidence based medicine, as well as, what is practically available and possible in our setting. Please discuss patients with our Lead Medical Providers, who have experience treating patients in our unique setting. Even relatively common conditions may be treated differently in our setting for a variety of reasons. The Lead Medical providers are there to ensure that the treatment each of our patients receives, meets Floating Doctors' standards. Treatment plans may differ between the communities also, depending on the local resources and closest health care facilities.

Usually present with subjective fever that can be taken as genuine in this setting.

Temperature > 38 Degrees Celsius.

Chills, rigors, sepsis.

Although the fever is frequently of viral origin, serious illness must be excluded [1]
    - Viral, bacterial, or parasitic infection
    - Pneumonia.
    - Pyelonephritis.
    - Dengue.
    - Malaria (less likely).
    - Bacterial meningitis.
    - Skin infections.
    - Malignancy.
    - Vasculitis/Autoimmune disorders.

Full intake, including Blood pressure, respiratory rate and heart rate.

Establish pattern and duration of fever.

History - review of systems. Examination - each organ system.

For children:
    - Check skin, throat, ears and lungs for source.
    - Ask about GI symptoms and seizures.
    - Urine dipstick test.

Temperature >38 degrees Celsius.

Axillary temperature underestimates core body temperature by approximately 0.5 degrees Celsius. [2] 

0.5 degrees Celsius will be added to any axillary measurements at intake.

Infants (aged 0-28 days)
“All febrile neonates aged 0-28 days old should be hospitalized for presumed sepsis and treated with antibiotics pending culture results (48 hours)." [3,4]

Infants (aged 28-90 days)
“All febrile infants aged 28-60 days, after having a sepsis evaluation, should be hospitalized and empirically started on intravenous antibiotics pending culture results.” [3]

Infants aged 28-90 days will require a number of investigations for which hospitalization is necessary. 

Regardless of hospitalization outcome, these children still require follow-up every 24 hours until the fever has resolved and all cultures are negative." [5]

Infants (aged 3 months-3 years)
“Febrile children aged 3 months to 3 years are evaluated based on epidemiologic and focal findings revealed during the history taking and physical examination as well as whether or not these children are at low risk for serious bacterial infections." [3,6]

Identification and appropriate management depends on the underlying cause. In the case of self-limiting viral infections, the only management required is advice and reassurance.

If meningococcal disease is suspected, give parenteral antibiotics at the earliest opportunity (Ceftriaxone - see essential medications for doses) and urgent evacuation to a hospital.

Health Education for patients and relatives:
Stress importance of adequate, and increased fluid intake.

Do not wear too many clothes or use too many blankets.

Don't wipe the sweat off immediately as this helps to cool the body.

Cool baths and tepid sponging are not recommended.

Child:
Paracetamol/Acetaminophen: 15 mg/kg every 8 hours as needed. 

(2nd line - Ibuprofen. 1-2 months: 5 mg/kg every 8 hours as needed, >2 months: 5-10 mg/kg every 8 hours as needed).

Adult:
Paracetamol 500mg – 1g every 6 - 8 hours as needed (Maximum 4g/24 hours). 

(2nd line: Ibuprofen 200 – 400 mg every eight hours as needed).

Higher dosing of NSAIDs is not recommended in this region due to chronic dehydration and renal impairment.

Don't use Ibuprofen/aspirin in pregnant/breastfeeding women and avoid in those with peptic ulcer disease. 

Avoid Ibuprofen in children with fever and skin lesions, a rare adverse effect is worsening of skin lesions in chicken pox, which can be very serious. Paracetamol is the drug of choice.

In our setting one of the most common causes is dehydration [1]. Awareness of this and advice to patients to increase oral intake is therefore vital.

Other causes include, but are not limited to [2]:

Primary Headache
    - Tension
    - Migraine
    - Cluster headache

Secondary Headache
   - The list of causes of secondary headaches is exhaustive and can be found elsewhere [1,3]. It is included but not limited to: meningitis, giant cell arteritis, sinusitis and visual problems.

History
    - Establish patient’s normal fluid intake. Most of population drink only 1-3 glasses of water a day, often while working in the sun!
    - A good history is critical to the diagnosis and management of headache. Particular attention must be paid to red flags [4]:
        - New onset headache.
        - Onset after age 50 years.
        - Change in pattern of headache.
        - Worsening headache.
        - Acute or sudden onset.
        - Sudden onset during exertion, with coughing, with sneezing, sex-related.
        - Headache with postural link (worse after lying down could be a sign of intracranial hypertension).
        - Headache in a setting of malignancy or HIV.
        - Systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss, cough).
        - Neurologic symptoms or signs.

Exam
- Normal intake will be performed. In case of red flags, ensure a full neurological exam is performed - including fundoscopy (to rule out papilloedema).

Whilst access to investigations during Floating Doctors’ clinics will be somewhat limited, a simple history and examination will be ascertain the cause in most scenarios.

If any red flags or concerning features are elicited, please discuss with a Lead Medical Provider. Depending on the urgency of the situation, we can:
    - Arrange an emergency hospital appointment.
    - Attempt to expedite secondary care at a later date.

1. Simple Dehydration Headache/Tension Headache
    - Check lying and standing BP (if postural symptoms).
Health Education [5]
    - Encourage ways to increase fluid intake (i.e., coconut juice, filtered/boiled water, soups, fruit, vegetables).
    - Explain importance of water in body.
    - Advise reduction of caffeinated beverages.
    - Explain that as a gross marker when urine is clear, they have drank enough water.

Pharmacological Treatment
     - First line: Paracetamol/Acetaminophen 500mg - 1g as needed every 6 - 8 hours (maximum 4g/24hrs). 
     - Advise only to take after they have drank 1 litre of water and if they still have the headache.

2. Migraines [5,6]
Health Education
    - Advice about triggers (i.e., coffee, cheese, stress).
    - Encourage a symptom diary where the patient can recognize their triggers.

Pharmacological Treatment
    - Acute: Combination of an NSAID and an antiemetic (i.e., ibuprofen 200 - 400 mg and metoclopramide 10mg).
    - Chronic: Regular prophylactic medication can be considered if the patient is having more than 2 migraines per month[5,6,7]. Assess for contraindications or cautions for B-blockers (if not contraindicated by asthma, heart failure, peripheral vascular disease or depression).
        - First line: Atenolol 50 mg once a day.
        - Second line: Amitriptyline 12.5mg once at night, increase to 25 mg if tolerated.
        
Other causes of headache can include; sinusitis, neck pathology, dental pathology, and otitis media. Always look for red flags for dengue (if current outbreak), meningitis, malaria (if patient has been to endemic region), space occupying lesions and intracranial bleeds.

Any concerns the headache is not a simple dehydration headache, ensure a full neurological examination including fundoscopy, in a dark room, is performed (to rule out papilloedema). Discuss cases with the floating LMP.

“Musculoskeletal pain is a known consequence of repetitive strain, overuse, and work-related musculoskeletal disorders. These injuries include a variety of disorders that cause pain in bones, joints, muscles, or surrounding structures. The pain can be acute or chronic, focal or diffuse. Low back pain is the most common example of chronic musculoskeletal pain. Other examples include tendonitis and tendinosis, neuropathies, myalgia, and stress fractures [1].”

- Many patients describe a long history of generalized muscular pain, worse after work.
- Knee pain tends to be due to osteoarthritis.
- Back pain tends to be due to poor posture, particularly when lifting heavy objects.
- Shoulder and elbow pain tends to be from repetitive use (with machete or washing clothes).

History
    - A thorough history can often elucidate a likely cause. Exclude history of direct trauma, deformity, or acute pathology (ongoing infection/ septic joint).
    - For back pain, pay particular attention to red flag features [1,2]:
        - Thoracic pain.
        - Age of onset less than 20 or more than 55 years.
        - Loss of control of the bowel or bladder.
        - Weakness or numbness in a leg or arm.
        - Foot drop, disturbed gait.
        - High fever.
        - Saddle anaesthesia (numbness of the anus, perineum or genitals, ask about sensation when wiping).
        - History of carcinoma.
        - Structural deformity.

Examination
    - Depending on the affected joint, it is necessary to perform a focused examination to guide management and follow up.
    - If back pain is associated with bowel/bladder incontinence or saddle anaesthesia, a perform a DRE/PR [3]. 
    - Similarly, neurological examination can be useful if a patient has neurological symptoms.

Health Education [4]
- Give appropriate exercises and stretches.
 
- Physiotherapy can be extremely beneficial.

- Heat packs made with a cloth and warm water.

- Advice on posture, moving, and handling techniques.

- Reassurance that muscular pain is normal after hard work and it tends to subside with time. 

- Advise them to return to next clinic or seek further medical advice if needed.

- Weight Loss where appropriate (overweight with osteoarthritis in lower limb joints).

Pharmacological Treatment:

Chronic Musculoskeletal Pain.
- Paracetamol/Acetaminophen 500mg - 1g as needed every 6-8 hours (4g/24hrs maximum).
    
Acute Musculoskeletal Pain/Inflammation.
- Ibuprofen 200 - 400 mg three times a day as needed. 
(NOT FOR REPEAT PRESCRIPTIONS, see side effects and contraindications of NSAIDs).

Neuropathic pain (This could be diabetic neuropathy or a condition such as sciatica).
- Amitriptyline 12.5 mg at night, increased after a week to 25mg.

Also see section on joint injections if appropriate.

If any alarming symptoms are elicited, hospital work-up either as an inpatient (in emergencies) or as an outpatient can be facilitated.

Indications for Intra-articular Joint Injection include:
- Arthritis.
- Bursitis.
- Tendinopathy.
- Tenosynovitis.
- Enthesopathy.

- Hypersensitivity – local or systemic.

- Tissue atrophy, nodule formation and skin hypopigmentation.

- Tendon Rupture.

- Infection, local or systemic.

- Post injection flare of symptoms - usually short lived up to 48 hrs.

- Facial flushing – usually 24-72 hours post injection and predominantly women.

- Menstrual irregularity.

- Elevated blood sugar in diabetic patients.

- Fainting.

- Steroid induced osteonecrosis or arthropathy.

- Known Allergy. 

- Local or systemic infection.

- Active rash / broken skin at site of injection.

- Uncontrolled Coagulopathy.

- Fracture/unstable joint.

- Tendon regions at high risk of rupture. 

- Injection into a prosthetic joint.

Informed consent (below) - most important report signs of infection urgently.

Screen for any contraindications. 

Draw up local anaesthetic and steroid and discard needle(s).

Attach new sterile needle(s).

Mark site (e.g. using needle cover). N.b. Injecting through ink risks tattooing skin.

Clean area with appropriate topical antiseptic.

Aspirate pre-injection to ensure vessel not entered.

Inject using no touch technique (unless full sterility observed).

See online video links below for techniques for shoulder, knee and elbow injections.

Cover site with sterile dressing.

The patients should be advised to remain in clinic for 20 minutes post injection.

Relative rest for 24 to 48 hours post injection, particularly if the knee is injected.

Review patient at 24 – 48 hours.

Warn patient about steroid flare of symptoms (usually short lived up to 48 hrs) & advise patient it may be up to 5 days before benefit noted.

Immediate relief from the anaesthetic as evidence of good placement of the injection.

Decrease the propensity of the glucocorticoid to cause atrophy.

Decrease glucocorticoid crystals acting as irritant or pro-inflammatory factor (so-called post injection flare) before the biochemical effect of the glucocorticoid takes over.

The patient should be informed about the relevant risks and benefits of the injection. The clinician should document that such a discussion has taken place and that the patient has consented to the treatment.

Infection Risks
A rare complication of joint and soft tissue injection.  Hand mediated transmission is the major factor contributing to healthcare associated infection. Patient skin preparation is recommended prior to surgical procedures to reduce risk of infection.  However, the absence of skin prep in clinic should not be considered an absolute contraindication to proceeding with a joint injection. Before skin preparation, the skin should be free of visible dirt. The skin preparation should be applied in concentrically enlarging circles beginning at the site of proposed injection. Alcohol based, chlorhexidine based and iodine based preparation are all suitable.

Tendon Rupture
There have been case reports of tendon rupture following steroid injection and ingestion. Biopsy studies have demonstrated reduced cell viability and proliferation, reduced collagen synthesis and organisation, and reduced strength as a result of tendon exposure to steroid. Therefore, it is generally best to avoid injecting steroid into the body of a tendon and, unless strongly indicated, avoid steroid injections in the vicinity of tendons at high risk of rupture due to pathology (severe tendinopathy) or anatomical location (Achilles).

Osteonecrosis
The risk of osteonecrosis is highest with prolonged, high doses of exogenous steroids, particularly in the presence of other risk factors. Short courses of steroids however have also been shown to increase the risk of this rare complication.

Anticoagulation and joint injection
If the INR <4.5 then it is generally considered safe to proceed as bleeding risks are very low. However, it is unlikely the patient will have had a recent INR so you may need to refer the patient to a specialist or for an INR or consider other treatment options. Analgesia options are often limited in these patients. The decision to do these injections in patients who are anti-coagulated requires careful consideration. The risk of halting anticoagulation is often higher than the small risk of bleeding complications, but this should always be weighed. A management plan in the event of bleeding should be discussed with the patient in advance. We have few patients receiving warfarin treatment.

Steroid Type and Frequency
Dexamethasone and Methylprednisolone are the two injectable steroids commonly available to Floating Doctors. There have been some suggestion of cartilage damage after steroid injection but no definitive evidence. Systematic Reviews (Stevens et al and Douglas 2012) have both concluded similarly, the frequency of injections should be guided by clinical diagnosis, treatment aims, professional opinion and experience. UpToDate provides more recent evidence (Oct 2018) advising against serial steroid injections due to concerns about potential negative effects on cartilage and disease progression; no number is cited as being safe of unsafe.

Menstrual Irregularity & Cushing’s Syndrome
Systemic absorption of steroid has been shown to affect the hypothalamic- pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis after steroid joint injections. This can last up to four weeks after a single injection, occasionally longer, depending on the dose and frequency of injections. This is the mechanism thought to affect menstruation.   Rare cases of Cushing’s syndrome have been reported but generally using unusually high doses and frequencies. HIV patients on antiretrovirals are more susceptible to iatrogenic Cushing’s syndrome. Careful consideration should be given to this complication if multiple or repeat steroid injections are going to be undertaken. 

Soft tissue atrophy
This is an uncommon complication of steroid injection even in superficial dermatological procedures involving steroid injection.
Hyperglycaemia – Intra-articular steroid injections have been shown to elevate blood sugar in diabetic patients, starting after a few hours and lasting for several days, sometimes longer. These increases in glycaemia are statistically significant but for most patients not clinically significant. However, diabetic patients should be warned of this effect. 

Anaphylaxis
According to the resuscitation council UK website, the time course for cardiopulmonary arrest resulting from injected medication predominantly occurs between 2- 20 minutes post injection. Patients should be asked to stay for the full 20 minutes.

Patients, typically children, present with acute or chronic rashes. Often these are nonspecific and the underlying diagnosis can seem unclear.

Common types of skin rash that we encounter include:
    - Scabies.
    - Impetigo.
    - Seborrhoeic dermatitis.
    - Folliculitis.
    - Insect bites.
    - Cutaneous leishmaniasis.

It is important to be aware that skin rash can be due to more sinister causes [1]. These include meningococcal disease, malignancy, non-accidental injury or TB.

Children in the communities are usually fully vaccinated, and often the mothers will have a card to prove it. Thankfully this makes a lot of the more serious infections less likely. If you are in doubt regarding vaccinations as the mother for the child's card or ask the Lead Medical Provider if the community in question has a good vaccine program (some communities have less access than others unfortunately).

    - Where is/are the lesion(s) (check mucous membranes)?
    - Provoking or relieving factors
    - Associated symptoms: Itch, tenderness, bleeding or discharge, systemic symptoms

A high proportion of the cases we see will be infective. Therefore, measures to prevent spread can be useful. These include [2,4]:

    - Please hand soap to the patient.
    - Avoidance of itching.
    - Use a tissue, or cough and sneeze into your arm, not your hand. Turn away from other people.

Pharmacological
Eczematous/Dermatitis Rash.

    (Coconut oil (aceite de coco), Calamine lotion, Oatmeal bath, E45). 
  - Second line: Trial of Hydrocortisone 1%.

Wounds/Superficial Secondary Bacterial Infections.
  - Clean the wound with clean water and soap and iodine.
  - Counsel the Patient regarding maintaining the wound and avoiding the ocean.
  - Do not use triple antibiotic cream (unless impetigo), supply iodine to the patient to take home with counselling on how to use.
  - If the infection needs antibiotic treatment, give antibiotics as per cellulitis or impetigo guidelines depending on the clinical presentation.

Heat stroke.

General Principles for Diarrhoea and Dehydration in infants/children [2-4]:

Tell carer to...

1. Give extra fluids.
- More frequent and longer duration of breastfeeding.
- If not exclusively breastfeeding or not taking the breast give ORS/SSS 10 ml/kg/hr or food with liquid content.
- After each loose stool give extra fluid.
- Up to 2 years: 50 to 100 ml after each loose stool 2 years or more: 100 to 200 ml after each loose stool.

2. Continue feeding
- Restart food as early as possible, good foods include banana, cereals, bread: avoid sugary foods.

3. Seek medical attention if...
- Dry mouth/lips.
- Lack of tears.
- Not keeping any fluid down.
- Not making urine/Dry nappies. Lethargic/confused.


If a child looks moderately dehydrated or you have any concerns... 

Give the child ORS in clinic and observe closely over 4 hours.
    - If patient not improving, then consider IV fluids or hospital admission. Ideally review patient again in 24 hours.


Give Zinc supplements OD 10 days (2 - 6 months: 10mg, 6 months–5 years: 20mg).
    - If available zinc decreases the length of diarrhoeal illness and decreases the recurrence of diarrhoeal illnesses [5].

Malnutrition refers to a nutrient deficiency state of protein, energy or micronutrients [1].

In adults, the Body Mass Index can be used to detect malnutrition. A BMI below 18.5 is classed as underweight [2]. Beware of solely using this to diagnose malnutrition however as oedema can mask weight loss in some circumstances [3]. Other signs in adults include [4]: somnolence, frequent infections, delayed wound healing and poor concentration.

For children, the WHO criteria for identifying children with severe malnutrition are [4,5]:
    - Bipedal oedema.
    - Visible severe wasting.
    - Weight for height more than three standard deviations below the median of international reference population.

Look for signs of the following 3 clinical syndromes (mixed pictures may occur) [6]:
    - “Marasmus: Obvious loss of weight with gross reduction in muscle mass, especially from limb girdles. Subcutaneous fat virtually absent. Thin, atrophic skin lies in folds. Alopecia and brittle hair. Sometimes, appearance of lanugo hair.
    - Kwashiorkor: Usually occurs in children aged 1-2 years with changing hair colour to red, grey or blonde. Moon facies, swollen abdomen (pot belly), hepatomegaly and pitting oedema. Dry, dark skin which splits were stretched over pressure areas, to reveal pale areas.
    - Nutritional dwarfism: Patient is small for age. Face shape may be affected by size of teeth.”

There are a number of risk factors that place individuals at a higher risk of malnutrition. These include [6,7]: extremely young age, poverty, coexisting chronic illness or developmental delay and mental health problems.

Relatively common in the communities we visit. The most common symptoms of scabies, itching and a skin rash, are caused by sensitization (a type of “allergic” reaction) to the proteins and feces of the parasite. Severe itching (pruritus), especially at night, is the earliest and most common symptom of scabies. A pimple-like (papular) itchy (pruritic) “scabies rash” is also common. In this climate itching and rash may affect the whole body or be limited to common sites (between the fingers, wrist,elbow, armpit and penis). [1]

Scabies is an itchy rash caused by the parasitic mite Sarcoptes scabiei [2].

Risk Factors are overcrowding, poverty, poor nutritional status, poor hygiene, children, immunocompromised individuals and elderly [3]. The elderly, and immunocompromised individuals are at particular risk of the crusted variant. They tend to present with clinically atypical lesions and are often misdiagnosed, causing a delay in appropriate treatment and increased risk of a local epidemic.
The diagnosis is largely clinical. A magnifying lens may help in identification of burrows or even occasionally mites [4]. If in doubt the case can be posted with images on SERMO.

- Treat whole family, where possible, wash bedding, hammocks and clothes in very hot water and leave to try in direct sunlight.
- Soap.
-The primary  method of treatment for scabies is by either oral anthelmintic (ivermectin), or topical application of a parasiticidal preparation (permethrin) overnight to the whole body from head to toe. Which agent to use is dependant on the weight of the patient, if the patient is pregnant or if the patient is breast feeding. Treatment is should be repeated a week later. If there is secondary bacterial infection present, this should be treated first with antibiotics for 24-48 hours in the case of permethrin to avoid systemic absorption.

- For Patients < 15kg, Pregnant or Breastfeeding (Ivermectin contraindicated in all three)
    - Permethrin cream 5% (for children over 2 months), applied to body on day 1 and day 8.
                        *Apply at night
                        *Avoid face.
                        *Advise wrap hands to avoid ingestion in infants. 
                        *Don't apply to broken/inflamed skin. 
                        *Treat secondary infection first with antibiotic for 24-48 hours.
                        *Do not apply after a hot bath (as this increases systemic absorption and removes the drug from its treatment site). 

- For Patients 15kg+
    - Ivermectin 200 mcg/kg once on day 1 and day 8.

-Ivermectin 200 mcg/Kg oral and Permethrin 5% cream if patient over 15kg and not pregnant or breastfeeding.
-Patients with crusted 'Norwegian' scabies may require two or three applications of permethrin on consecutive days to ensure that enough penetrates the hyperkeratotic areas to kill all the mites.
-Patients are often immunocompromised (consider Malnutrition, HIV etc).

Leishmaniasis is caused by a protozoan of the genus Leishmania [1]. The presentation of Leishmaniasis varies according to the species causing the infection and the region in the world where a person is infected. There are 3 main types of Leishmaniasis [2,3]:
    - Visceral
    - Cutaneous
    - Mucocutaneous

This section will focus on cutaneous Leishmaniasis since this is the type that is mainly present in Panama [2]. Lesions start mostly on exposed regions of the skin which are easily bitten by sandflies. The lesions start as erythematous patches that change to plaques and ulcers. Unless there is a secondary bacterial infection, the lesions are usually painless. Many patients have limited cutaneous lesions that self-cure within 6-18 months, leaving scarred tissue.

‘Scattered cases of cutaneous and mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis occur in rural areas in the entire country, but most cases are reported from western Panama (Bocas del Toro, Cocle, Colon, Chiriqui and Panama Provinces) and from the west-central areas [4].’

L. panamensis is responsible for the great majority of the cases, mostly in forested areas from west to east, including Bocas del Toro [5]. The two-toed sloth is the main reservoir [5,6].

In cases where Leishmaniasis is suspected, consult with a Lead Medical Provider.

The diagnosis and treatment of Leishmaniasis can be provided free of charge through MINSA. For the diagnosis of Cutaneous Leishmaniasis, parasitological testing is required [7]. The number of cases of diagnosed Cutaneous Leishmaniasis from 2009 is represented in the diagram above [8]:

The following considerations need to be made prior to referral for treatment
- Number, size, evolution and persistence of lesions, location of lesions (e.g. on the face), other features ie lymphangitis.

Local alternative treatments include 
- Heat treatment, cryotherapy, and topical amphotericin. 
- In these communities many lesions are treated with ‘local treatment’ which may or may not improve the underlying condition.

Medical treatment
- Treatment usually occurs in the closest Centro de Salud, based on clinical diagnosis and usually without monitoring of kidney or liver function. 
- Standard treatment in Panama is a course of IM Pentavalent Antimony for 21 days, which can cause reno-hepatotoxicity.
- We tend to treat secondary infections and advise and support patients to seek treatment if there are multiple lesions, lesions on the face, large lesions or worsening lesions. 
- As for smaller lesions, which will likely heal spontaneously, the risk of treatment may be larger than the risk of the lesions causing significant morbidity.

[9]

The cutaneous form differs from the visceral variety and doesn’t transform to Visceral Leishmaniasis (except in rare cases of immunocompromise in HIV). In certain regions of Central and South America with the Vianna subspecies, 5% of the cutaneous form may develop into Mucocutaneous form (sometimes years after the initial infection), which typically affects the nasal mucosa and is destructive in nature. However, in our region of Panama this seems to be very rare, despite the most likely leishmania species being from the Vianna subspecies (L. Panamensis). [10]. 

Other complications of Cutaneous Leishmaniasis include [10,11]: bleeding, superimposed infections due to immunodeficiency and disfigurement.

“Cellulitis appears as a swollen, red area of skin that feels hot and tender. It can spread rapidly to other parts of the body. Cellulitis isn't usually spread from person to person.
Skin on lower legs is most commonly affected, though cellulitis can occur anywhere on your body or face.” [1]
“The most common causative organisms are Streptococcus or Staphylococcus spp. but they can be caused by a wide range of both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.” [2]

Usually the diagnosis is clinical and no investigations are required. If investigations are required, the ones likely to be of benefit will be in a hospital setting.
The basic vital signs and clinical examination can be utilised to inspect for clinical features of sepsis. [3]

Check vital signs to screen for sepsis.

Check random blood sugar as diabetes is a risk factor and uncontrolled blood sugar will affect healing.

General measures include rest, elevation of any affected limbs, and analgesia (paracetamol or ibuprofen) [4]

1st line
Children >25kg - Adults:  Cloxacillin 10-14 days 500mg 4 times a day.
Children <25kg:  Amoxicillin 10-14 days.
1–4 years 250 mg 3 times a day. 5–11 years 500 mg 3 times a day.

If severe or not improving after 48-72 hours, then add in second line.

2nd line 
Children >25kg - Adults: Clindamycin 150–300 mg 4 times a day, 10-14 days.
Children <25kg: Azithromycin 5 days. 
6 months-17 years: 10 mg/kg once a day (max 500mg per dose).

Complications are uncommon but may include: abscess formation, gangrene, thrombophlebitis/lymphangitis, chronic leg oedema (a late complication which may predispose to further episodes of infection).

Less common complications (occurring in <1%) include: necrotising fasciitis, osteomyelitis, compartment syndrome, acute glomerulonephritis, endocarditis, septicaemia, streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.

For skin abscess, treatment is incision and drainage (earliest clinic day to enable one follow up) AND oral antibiotics.
Children >25kg - Adults: Clindamycin 150mg - 300mg 4 times a day for 5-7 days.
Children <25kg: Amoxicillin 5-7 days. 1-4 years 250 mg 3 times a day, 5-11 years 500mg 3 times a day.

“Folliculitis is a common skin condition in which hair follicles become inflamed. It's usually caused by a bacterial or fungal infection. At first it may look like small red bumps or white-headed pimples around hair follicles — the tiny pockets from which each hair grows. The infection can spread and turn into non healing, crusty sores.
The condition isn't life-threatening, but it can be itchy, sore and embarrassing. Severe infections can cause permanent hair loss and scarring.” [171]

“Damaged follicles are at risk of infection. The most common causes of follicle damage are:

    - Heat and sweat, such as that caused by wearing rubber gloves or waders

    - Injuries to your skin, such as from scrapes or surgical wounds
    - Coverings on your skin, such as plastic dressings or adhesive tape” [172]
The diagnosis is based on history and examination findings.

General Measures
    - Avoid precipitating factors such as inappropriate clothing.
    - Use separate washing implements and towels from other members of the household.

Pharmacological treatment
    - Mild, superficial folliculitis may resolve with hygiene measures and without medical treatment.
    - Treat deeper folliculitis as per cellulitis. [172,173]

Impetigo is a very common superficial infection of the skin. It can be divided into non-bullous and bullous forms. The non-bullous types represent the majority of cases.

Non-bullous impetigo starts as tiny pustules or vesicles that evolve rapidly into crusted plaques that tend to be under 2 cm in diameter. It usually starts on the face or on the extremities where bites, scratches, burns or trauma have occurred. It spreads rapidly. Little or no surrounding erythema or oedema. Regional lymph nodes are often enlarged.
Bullous impetigo has a thin roof and tend to rupture spontaneously. They are usually on the face, trunk, extremities, buttocks, or perineal regions. More likely to occur on top of other disease like atopic eczema. [1]

Impetigo - In the UK Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism, Streptococcus pyogenes is the other pathogen involved, and on occasions both organisms can be found together. In warmer climates Streptococcus pyogenes is more prevalent.

Bullous impetigo - Is nearly always caused by Staphylococcus aureus. [2]
The diagnosis is usually based on history and clinical examination findings.

General advice [3,4,5,6]
“Advise good hygiene measures to prevent spread (also to other people):
- Keep the affected area(s) clean and dry
- Wash hands after touching affected area(s).
- Avoid sharing of towels and bathwater.
- Avoid scratching the affected area. Keep fingernails short and clean.” Children can use mittens to prevent scratching.
 
Localised impetigo:
- Soap and water twice a day.
- Triple antibiotic cream 2 - 3 times a day for 3 - 5 days.

Complicated / Widespread / Severe Impetigo:

1st line: 
Children >25kg - Adults: Cloxacillin 500mg 4 times a day, 5-7 days.
Children <25kg: Amoxicillin 5-7 days.
1–4 years 250 mg 3 times a day. 5–11 years 500 mg 3 times a day.

Review 48 - 72 hours, if not improving switch or add in second line if very severe.

Second line: Azithromycin 3 days. 
6 months - 17 years: 10 mg/kg once a day (max/adult dose 500mg once a day).
Cellulitis, lymphangitis, suppurative lymphadenitis, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome may occur occasionally. [7]

Candidiasis often presents with soreness and itching.

Depending on the different forms of cutaneous candidiasis the appearance may vary:
    - Red, moist skin area, possibly pustules or papules, yellow-white scale on the surface (looks like curds).

There are different forms of cutaneous candidiasis, the most frequent:
    - Intertrigo (skin fold infection).
    - Candidal nail infections - chronic paronychia or onychomycosis.
    - Napkin dermatitis.
    - Balanitis.
    - Mucocutaneous candidiasis.
    - Candidal folliculitis.

[1]

The following factors increase the likelihood of candidiasis occurring [1,2]:
    - Irritated or damaged skin
    - Patients taking antibiotics
    - Poorly controlled diabetes
    - Immunodeficiency e.g. HIV
    - Menopause
    - Pregnancy

In our clinical setting, access to investigations is limited. Diagnosis will be clinical based on the patient’s clinical presentation. If you are in doubt, liaise with a Lead Medical Provider. If you are still struggling consider adding the case to SERMO.

General measures: 
Avoid occlusion of skin, avoid obesity, keep skin dry, expose area to air when appropriate, wash with emollients as soap substitutes and dry thoroughly after washing.

Pharmacological treatment:
Clotrimazole 1% cream twice per day - Continue until 1 week after lesions have disappeared
If there is problematic itch or inflammation, consider adding a mild corticosteroid cream (Hydrocortisone cream) for 7-14 days.
Consider systemic oral treatment with fluconazole 50mg/day or fluconazole 150mg once weekly for 2-4 weeks if: topical treatment is ineffective, there is widespread infection or if the patient is immunocompromised.

Nappy rash: Apply zinc oxide for 2-3 weeks. If severe treat with clotrimazole cream 1%, 2-3 times a day for 7 days.

Oral candidiasis: Oral nystatin 7 days. 
Child 1 month-1 year: 200,000 IU 4 times a day.
Children 2-17 years: 400,000 IU 4 times a day.
Adults 600,000 IU 4 times a day.

Vaginal candidiasis - see urogynaecology section.

Invasive candidiasis can develop. This term encompasses the conditions candidaemia and deep-seated tissue candidiasis. If you suspect either of these conditions, urgent admission to hospital is necessary. [4]

Patients knowledge of wound care is generally poor in this area. Initially assess the wound and the need for closure. Assess [1,2,3] the mode of injury, time of injury, type of wound, location (proximity to major vessels and nerves), shape of the wound, depth and direction. Also check to for the presence of a potential foreign body and for underlying structural injury.

The next step is to achieve haemostasis [4]. This can be spontaneous but may require pressure or elevation. Do not use a tourniquet.[4,5]

Please be aware of the fact that often the patient will be in a lot of pain! Analgesia is therefore essential.

In case needed use lidocaine as a local anaesthetic [4,5] (up to 3 mg/kg. NB: a 1% solution contains 10 mg/mL). E.g. If a patient weighs 70 kg, use no more than 210mg. This would be 21 ml of lidocaine 1%.

The next step is to clean the area extensively and remove debris. Use saline 0.9% where possible [6]. If this is not available, use tap water. Tap water has been shown to have as low, or lower, infection rates as proprietary antiseptic solutions [7].

Wound Closure - The timing of wound closure will be based on your assessment of the wound [6,7]:
    - Primary closure: immediate closure can be used for simple wounds <12 hours old with opposable edges. Delayed primary closure: if there is high risk of infection, give prophylactic antibiotics and close after a few days provided there is no infection. This is something that can be done on a follow up day if planned appropriately.
    - Secondary closure: allow the wound to close by itself if a bite (except on the face) or it has separated edges or infection. This may result in increased scarring.


Type of Closure [6,7,8]
    - If primary closure is decided upon, generally we have 3 options available: steristrips, tissue adhesives and/or sutures. Bear in mind that sutures will need to be removed. Often this can be problematic in our setting so if this option is chosen an appropriate removal plan is essential.
    - Steristrips can be used for small wounds or to allow for drainage where needed.
    - For small superficial lacerations, consider the use of tissue adhesives [12] if available.
    - If sutures are used, advise regarding appropriate follow up. Teach patient or carer to remove sutures in a hygienic way if follow up is not possible. Another option is to consult with a Lead Medical Provider or the Clinic Manager. In some clinic locations there are health workers who are trained to remove sutures. Ensuring that these health workers follow up the wound care after we're gone can be useful.

The following guidelines provide a rough idea of when sutures should be removed [2,4]:
    - Face: 4 - 5 days
    - Neck: 7 days
    - Arms and back of hands: 7 days
    - Scalp, chest, abdomen or back: 7 - 10 days
    - Legs and top of feet: 10 days
    - Palms, soles, fingers or toes: 12 - 14 days
    - Overlying a joint: 12 - 14 days

Features that increase the probability of asthma in adults include [55, 56,57]:
    - More than one of the following symptoms: wheeze, breathlessness, chest tightness and cough, particularly if:
        - Symptoms are worse at night and in the early morning.
        - Symptoms are present in response to exercise, allergen exposure and cold air.
        - Symptoms are present after taking aspirin or beta-blockers.
    - History of atopic disorder.
    - Family history of asthma and/or atopic disorder.
    - Widespread wheeze heard on auscultation of the chest.
    - Otherwise unexplained low forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1) or peak expiratory flow (historical or serial readings).
    - Otherwise unexplained peripheral blood eosinophilia.

Frequently, an Asthma diagnosis is made on history and examination alone. Symptoms may include; chronic dry cough (particularly at night), wheeze, and excessive shortness of breath, exacerbated by cold air or exercise. Care must be taken with the differential diagnosis; in children wheezy bronchitis may be mistaken for asthma. In adults, COPD is the main alternative diagnosis. If tropical eosinophilia suspected, then a referral for a full blood count can be made.
For young children or those with difficulty using the inhaler, make a spacer with an empty water bottle. Ensure a tight seal, observe technique, and educate family

History
Undertake a structured clinical assessment to assess the initial probability of asthma. This should be based on:
    - History of recurrent episodes (attacks) of symptoms, ideally corroborated by variable peak flow when symptomatic and asymptomatic.
    - Symptoms of wheeze, cough, breathlessness and chest tightness that vary over time.
    - Recorded observation of wheeze heard by a healthcare professional.
    - Personal/ family history of other atopic conditions (particularly atopic eczema/ dermatitis, allergic rhinitis).
    - No symptoms/ signs to suggest alternative diagnoses.

Exam
'Not all asthma wheezes and all that wheezes is not asthma.'
    - Pay particular attention to pulse (which can be increased due to salbutamol use) and pattern of breathing.
    - Look for chest wall deformities
    - Peak Flow (simple and effective investigation that plays more of a role in the follow up of known asthmatics) [30,33]

Care must be taken with the differential diagnosis58:
    - In children wheezy bronchitis may be mistaken for asthma.
    - In adults, COPD is the main alternative diagnosis (ask about smoking and exposure to causative dusts).

Treat anyone presenting for the first time with a wheeze for potential tropical pulmonary eosinophilia with Albendazole59. This has the resultant effect of concomitant treatment of worms.

Management of chronic asthma

    - Inhaler technique is often poor in the communities we visit. Spending time with the patients optimizing their inhaler technique can be extremely effective.
    - Consider making a spacer with an empty water bottle. Ensure a tight seal, observe technique, and educate family.
    - Advise patients about symptoms to watch out for and to seek medical advice should these develop60. Asthma can potentially be life threatening. Therefore it is vital that patients are adequately educated about the condition.
    - Ensure dietary calcium requirements are met - inhaled corticosteroids can affect bone mineralisation. At Floating Doctors, we’re fairly limited with the availability of our medications. Medication choices are based on 2016 SIGN guidelines 56.

In severe cases, consider a short course of oral steroids and referral to hospital.
